bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 30, 1942

div1.p: Truby responds to Hench's letter of November 24, 1942. He justifies what he has written in his manuscript and clarifies several points that Hench has raised.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 30, 1942
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Nov. 30 /42
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks very much for your
letter of the 24th. I did not reply
sooner as I was awaiting the contracts
from Harpers. They came today and
seem satisfactory, but as no mention
was made of the number of illustrations
I am writing them that, if we can
agree on that point, the contract is
O.K. There is no hope of having the
books by Christmas as Mr. Mac Gregor
states in his letter of transmittal that “we
should have the books in three or four
months if wartime conditions do not
prevent.”

Regarding the two things you were
“concerned about”:-

1st The Walter Reed Lab. It was the
only nicely finished building the 2d Div.
Hospital had. Its shape, the Cupalo or ventilators,
and window trainings stand out in my
memory. It was not large and our
Q.M. could have moved it easily in one
AC
T
day I am sure. By laying a few
planks on the hard surface of the level
ground and placing rollers, or even
some of the large iron pipe we had
there, underneath the building it could
have been drawn about with a pair
of mules. Dr. Pinto identified the building
also when he was here. Col. Ash of the
museum had the negative made for
me from the large view of the Camp.

2d Regarding Neate's hand writing
in the Lab. book. I got that info from
Gen. Russell and he was most positive
about it. I have his letter somewheres
but can't locate it just now. I am glad
to change the wording of that sentence
and say “contains the handwriting of
Reed, Lazear and possibly Neate.
Suggest you write to Russell
one this.

I am not alarmed about what
literary critics may say. No one knows
how deficient I am in literary
matters better than I do. All I aimed
to do was to present the mass of information
I had before it was too late. I could have
done it better and easier 30 yrs. ago -
I did not want to
write this story.

Will keep you advised about the book.
Thanks again for your splendid cooperation
